contextId.information: The abstract noun "likeness" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "something similar to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the likeness of

contextId.information: The abstract noun "likeness" can be translated as an adjective, and the abstract noun "appearance" can be translated as a verb. AT: "As for what the living creatures looked like, they were similar to burning coals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: As for the likeness of the living creatures, their appearance was like burning coals

contextId.information: The abstract noun "likeness" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "all four of the wheels looked the same" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the four had the same likeness

contextId.information: The abstract noun "likeness" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "something similar to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the likeness of

contextId.information: The abstract noun "likeness" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "something similar to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the likeness of

contextId.information: The abstract noun "likeness" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "on what was similar to a throne there was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: on the likeness of the throne was

contextId.information: The abstract noun "likeness" can be translated as an adjective. The abstract noun "appearance" can be translated as a verb. If you need to tell who this is, you should probably identify him as Yahweh ([[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:01|1:3]]). AT: "something that looked similar to what appeared to be a man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: a likeness like the appearance of a man

contextId.information: The person's body above the hips looked like glowing metal that had fire in it. The abstract noun "appearance" can be translated as a verb. AT: "from what appeared to be his hips up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: from the appearance of his hips up

contextId.information: The abstract noun "appearance" can be translated as a verb. AT: "The brightness surrounding it appeared to be like the way a rainbow appears in the clouds on a rainy day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: Like the appearance of a rainbow in the clouds on a rainy day was the appearance of the bright light surrounding it

contextId.information: The abstract noun "appearance" can be translated as a verb. The abstract noun "likeness" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "It appeared to be something similar to the glory of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: It was the appearance of the likeness of the glory of Yahweh

contextId.information: The abstract nouns "lamentations," "mourning," and "woe" can be translated as adjectives. AT: "someone had written on it that these people would lament, be sad the way they would be if someone they loved had died, and have bad things happen to them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: written on it were lamentations, mourning, and woe

contextId.information: The abstract noun "likeness" can be translated as an adjective. The abstract noun "appearance" can be translated as a verb. AT: "something similar to a man, something that appeared to be a man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: a likeness with the appearance of a man

contextId.information: The abstract noun "appearance" can be translated as a verb. AT: "what appeared to be his hips ... what appeared to be something shining" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the appearance of his hips ... the appearance of something shining

contextId.information: Wrath is spoken of as if it were a liquid that Yahweh could pour out of a container. The word "Jerusalem" is a metonym for the people in the city. The abstract noun "outpouring" can be translated as a verb. AT: "when you pour out your wrath on Jerusalem" or "when you punish the people of Jerusalem because you are very angry with them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: in the outpouring of your wrath on Jerusalem

contextId.information: The abstract noun "appearance" can be translated as a verb. AT: "the wheels appeared to be like a beryl" or "what appeared to be wheels were like a beryl" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the appearance of the wheels was like a beryl

contextId.information: The abstract noun "appearance" can be translated as a verb. The abstract noun "likeness" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "All four of them appeared to be similar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: Their appearance was the same likeness for all four of them

contextId.information: The word "disgrace" can be expressed as a verb. AT: "about how he will disgrace them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: concerning their coming disgrace

contextId.information: This refers to poor and needy people. AT: "those who are poor and needy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the poor and needy

contextId.information: The abstract noun "appearance" can be translated as a verb. The abstract noun "likeness" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "appeared the way officers of chariot troops do, and they looked similar to sons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: had the appearance of officers of chariot troops, the likeness of sons

contextId.information: The abstract noun "disaster" can be translated using the adjective "terrible" or the verb "destroy." AT: "I will bring you to a terrible end" or "I will destroy you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: I will place disaster on you

contextId.information: The abstract noun "lamentation" can be translated using the verb "lament." AT: "begin to lament" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: begin a lamentation

contextId.information: The abstract noun "destruction" can be translated using the verb "destroy." AT: "at the time you are destroyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: on the day of your destruction

contextId.information: The abstract noun "lamentation" can be translated using the verb "lament." AT: "They will cry out and lament" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: They will lift up their wails of lamentation

contextId.information: The abstract nouns "wisdom" and "wealth" can be translated using the adjectives "wise" and "wealthy." AT: "By being very wise and by your trading, you have become more and more wealthy, so your heart is arrogant because of how wealthy you are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: By great wisdom and by your trading, you have multiplied your wealth, so your heart is arrogant because of your wealth

contextId.information: The abstract noun "splendor" can be translated using the adjective "splendid." AT: "profane how splendid you are" or "defile how majestic you are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: profane your splendor

contextId.information: The abstract nouns "model" and "perfection" can be translated using the words "completely" and "perfect." AT: "You were completely perfect" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: You were the model of perfection

contextId.information: The abstract nouns "beauty," wisdom" and "splendor" can be translated using the adjectives "beautiful," "wise" and "splendid." AT: Your heart was arrogant because you were beautiful; you became unwise because you were so splendid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: Your heart was arrogant with your beauty; you ruined your wisdom because of your splendor

contextId.information: The abstract noun "justice" can be translated using the verb "judge." AT: "when I judge all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: when I execute justice on all

contextId.information: The abstract noun "desolation" can be expressed with the adjective "desolate." AT: "For I will make the land of Egypt desolate" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: For I will make the land of Egypt a desolation

contextId.information: The abstract noun "confidence" can be translated with the verbs "trust" or "rely on."  AT: "The house of Israel will no longer trust in the Egyptians" or "The house of Israel will no longer rely on the Egyptians" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: The Egyptians will no longer be a reason for confidence for the house of Israel

contextId.information: The abstract nouns "reminder" and iniquity" can be expressed with the verbs "remind" and "sin." AT: "they will remind Israel of how Israel sinned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: they will be a reminder of the iniquity that Israel committed

contextId.information: The abstract noun "doom" can be translated with the phrase "terrible things will happen." AT: "a time when terrible things will happen to the nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: a time of doom for nations

contextId.information: The phrase "acts of judgment" refers to punishment. AT: "I will punish Thebes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: I will execute acts of judgment on Thebes

contextId.information: The phrase "acts of judgment" refers to punishment. AT: "I will punish Egypt in many ways" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: I will execute acts of judgment in Egypt

contextId.information: The abstract noun "terror" can be stated as "afraid." And here "nations" represents the people of the nations. AT: "who made the people of all the nations afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who were the terror of all the nations

contextId.information: The abstract noun "mourning" can be stated as a verb. AT: "and I made Lebanon mourn for the cedar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: and I brought mourning to Lebanon for him

contextId.information: Here "terror" represents a cause of terror or fear. AT: "Each warrior terrifies the nations" or "each one of them makes the nations afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: each warrior a terror of nations

contextId.information: Terror or fear is spoken of as if it were an object that someone could carry to another place. AT: "those who, when they were still alive, caused people to be extremely afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: those who brought terror on the land of the living

contextId.information: This can be put in active form. AT: "Her enemies killed them all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: all of them were killed

contextId.information: Terror or fear is spoken of as if it were an object that someone could carry to another place. See how you translated "brought terror" in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:32:22|32:23]]. AT: "those who, when they were still alive, caused people to be extremely afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: who brought their terrors

contextId.information: The abstract noun "righteousness" can be stated as the adjective "right." It is implied that they will not be saved from God's punishment. AT: "If righteous people start to sin, the fact that they did what was right before will not stop me from punishing them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: The righteousness of a righteous person will not save him if he sins!

contextId.information: The person think that because he was righteous Yahweh will not punish him, even if he sins. The abstract noun "righteousness" can be stated as the adjective "right." AT: "if he depends on the right things he has done." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: if he trusts in his righteousness

contextId.information: The abstract noun "wickedness" can be stated as the adjective "wicked." AT: "because of the wicked things he has done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: for the wickedness he committed

contextId.information: A "horror" is an abstract noun. It is something that makes people very afraid when they see it. AT: "and people will be afraid because of it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: and a horror

contextId.information: This can be stated to remove the abstract nouns "desolation" and "a horror." AT: "make you desolate and ruined" or "make you a desolate wasteland" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: make you a desolation and a horror

contextId.information: The abstract noun "desolation" can be stated as "desolate." AT: "Because you, mountains of Israel, have become desolate" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: Because of your desolation

contextId.information: The abstract noun "desolations" can be stated as "desolate cities." AT: "the desolate cities which have no people living in them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the uninhabited desolations

contextId.information: The abstract noun "breath" can be stated as the verb "breathe." AT: "I will make you able to breathe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: put breath within

contextId.information: The abstract noun "breath" can be stated as the verb "breathing." AT: "but they were not breathing" or "But they were not alive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: But there was still no breath in them

contextId.information: The abstract nouns "greatness" and "holiness" can be stated as adjectives. AT: "show that I am great and holy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: show my greatness and my holiness

contextId.information: "until you are satisfied" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: to your satisfaction

contextId.information: The abstract noun "drunkenness" can be stated as a adjective. AT: "until you become drunk" or "until you are intoxicated" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: until drunkenness

contextId.information: The abstract noun "appearance" can be translated as a verb. AT: "The way he appeared was like the way bronze appears" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: His appearance was like the appearance of bronze

contextId.information: The abstract noun "appearance" can be translated as a verb. AT: "just like what appeared in the vision" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: according to the appearance of the vision
